title: 204.13B — One-way lighting (3-plate ceiling rose): build flow + prove it (rig-safe)
description: Learn to construct a one-way lighting circuit using the three-plate method and verify its safety through systematic dead-testing procedures.
learningOutcomes: Build a one-way lighting circuit using a 3-plate ceiling rose with correct terminations and identification.
Apply a repeatable build flow from planning to recording results.
Carry out dead tests including CPC continuity, insulation resistance, and polarity logic.
Record test results clearly using correct units and pass/fail judgements.

outcomes.text: Identify the three terminal groups in a ceiling rose and their functions.
Explain the sequence of the rig-safe build flow (Plan-Mount-Route-Terminate-Inspect-Test).
Execute dead-testing procedures to confirm circuit integrity before energising.

content.title: The Systematic Build Flow
content.content:
To ensure a safe and professional installation, every electrician follows a repeatable **build flow**. This prevents errors and ensures the circuit is 'rig-safe' before any testing begins.

1. **Step 0 — Rig-safe start**: Confirm the training rig is isolated and in an approved dead state. Never start work until your workspace is clear and the correct circuit is identified.

2. **Step 1 — Plan from the diagram**: Before touching any cable, you must visualize the 'wire journey'. Identify where the **Loop (permanent live)** group is, which conductor is the **switch feed**, and which is the **switch return**. If you cannot explain the path of the electricity, do not start the build.

3. **Step 2 — Mount accessories**: Secure the consumer unit, switch box, and ceiling rose. Mechanical integrity is vital; accessories must be square and secure so that covers fit without crushing wires.

4. **Step 3 — Route and prepare cables**: Bring the cable **sheath into the accessories** to ensure no single-insulated cores are exposed. Apply identification immediately: **Green/Yellow sleeving** for CPCs and **Brown sleeving** for any conductor used as a live (especially the switch return).

5. **Step 4 — Terminate**: Follow the specific 3-plate map. The **Loop group** holds the CU Line and the Switch Feed. The **Neutral group** holds the CU Neutral and the Lamp Neutral. The **Switched Live group** holds the Switch Return and the Lamp Live. Finally, ensure the **CPC** is continuous and terminated at every point, including the switch box.

6. **Step 5 — Dead inspection**: Perform a visual check. Are there loose terminations? Is there copper showing outside terminals? Is the ID sleeving correct? Only proceed to testing if the inspection passes.

questions.questionText: Which terminal group in the ceiling rose connects the permanent live from the CU to the switch feed?
questions.hint: It is the 'middle' plate that stays live all the time.

questions.questionText: What colour sleeving must be applied to the blue core used as a switch return?
questions.hint: It indicates the conductor is acting as a live wire.

questions.questionText: Which test confirms there is no leakage path between the Line and Neutral conductors?
How does the connection in the 'Switched Live' terminal group differ from the 'Loop' terminal group in terms of its state when the switch is OFF?
questions.expectedAnswer: The Loop is always live, while Switched Live is only live when the switch is ON.
questions.hint: Think about which group is connected directly to the lamp live.

content.title: Your Turn: Build and Test Logic

questions.questionText: In a 3-plate rose, which two conductors share the 'Neutral' terminal block?
questions.hint: One comes from the supply, one goes to the bulb.

questions.questionText: What is the common DC voltage used for Insulation Resistance testing on a standard 230V lighting rig?
questions.hint: It is roughly double the nominal voltage.

questions.questionText: True or False: CPC sleeving is only required if the backbox is metal.
questions.hint: CPC must be identified and terminated at every point regardless of accessory material.

questions.questionText: Explain why a student must perform a 'Dead Inspection' and 'Continuity Test' BEFORE performing an 'Insulation Resistance' test. How do these steps protect the circuit and the person testing?
questions.expectedAnswer: Inspection and continuity ensure the circuit is physically correct and the earth path is intact. Testing IR at 500V on a poorly terminated or shorted circuit could cause damage or provide misleading results if the protective path isn't verified first.
questions.hint: Think about what 500V could do to a loose connection or a short circuit.
